docs.title: Dirk Petersen's Development Configuration

docs.text:

docs.title: Claude Code
docs.text: Documentation for Claude Code, an AI-powered development tool integrated into this workflow.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Claude Code provides AI-assisted development capabilities for code generation, analysis, and problem-solving. This setup uses AWS Bedrock for model inference, enabling local-first Claude Code execution.

docs.title: 1. Configure AWS Credentials
docs.text:
Add your AWS credentials to ~/.aws/credentials:

[bedrock]
aws_access_key_id = XXXXXXXXXXX
aws_secret_access_key = YYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY

docs.title: 2. Configure AWS Region
docs.text:
Add the Bedrock profile to ~/.aws/config:

[profile bedrock]
region = us-west-2

docs.title: 3. Install Claude Code
docs.text:
Install Claude Code globally via npm:

npm i -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code

docs.title: 4. Create Wrapper Script
docs.text:
Create a wrapper script at ~/bin/claude to simplify usage and model selection:

#! /bin/bash

export CLAUDE_CODE_USE_BEDROCK=1

export AWS_REGION=us-west-2
export AWS_PROFILE=bedrock
export ANTHROPIC_MODEL="anthropic.claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929-v1:0"
export ANTHROPIC_SMALL_FAST_MODEL="us.anthropic.claude-haiku-4-5-20251001-v1:0"

mymodel=${ANTHROPIC_SMALL_FAST_MODEL}
if [[ "$1" == "opus" ]]; then
  mymodel=$1
elif [[ "$1" == "sonnet" ]]; then
  mymodel="anthropic.claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929-v1:0"
fi

~/.claude/local/claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --model $mymodel $@

docs.title: 5. Make Script Executable and Add to PATH
docs.text:
First, create the ~/bin directory if it doesn't exist:

mkdir -p ~/bin

Make the script executable:

chmod +x ~/bin/claude

Add ~/bin to your PATH by adding this to your shell configuration (.bashrc, .zshrc):

export PATH="$HOME/bin:$PATH"

Reload your shell:

source ~/.bashrc  # or ~/.zshrc

docs.title: 6. Test Claude Code
docs.text:
Test that everything is set up correctly:

# Create a test directory
mkdir -p ~/test-project
cd ~/test-project
git init

# Launch Claude Code with default Haiku model
claude .

When Claude Code launches for the first time, it will: 1. Ask for your SSH keychain passphrase (cached for 4 hours) 2. Initialize the Claude Code environment 3. Start the interactive session in the git repository

docs.title: Important: Git Repository Requirement
docs.text: Claude Code must always be initialized inside a git repository. This is a requirement for the tool to function properly.

docs.title: Setting Up a Git Repository
docs.text: You have two options:

docs.title: Option 1: Create a Local Repository
docs.text:
mkdir my-project
cd my-project
git init

Then run Claude Code inside this directory:

claude .

docs.title: Option 2: Create a Repository on GitHub
docs.text:
1. Visit github.com/new to create a new repository
  2. Clone it to your local machine:
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/my-project.git
cd my-project
  1. Run Claude Code:
claude .

docs.title: Model Comparison
docs.text:
Understanding the differences between the three available models helps you choose the right tool for each task:

Aspect Haiku Sonnet Opus Speed ⚡ Fast ⚡⚡ Medium 🐌 Slow Cost 💰 $0.80/MTok 💰💰 $3.00/MTok 💰💰💰 $15.00/MTok Performance Excellent Very Good Superior Complex Tasks ⭐ ⭐⭐⭐ Medium ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ High Coding Skills ⭐⭐ Medium ⭐⭐⭐ Good ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ Excellent

docs.title: Default (Haiku - Fast)
docs.text:
Run Claude Code with the default fast Haiku model for quick fixes and simple tasks:

claude /path/to/project

Best for: - Quick bug fixes - Simple code generation - Refactoring small sections - Cost-conscious tasks

docs.title: Sonnet (Balanced)
docs.text:
Run with the balanced Sonnet model for most development work:

claude sonnet /path/to/project

Best for: - Complex feature development - Detailed code analysis - Medium-complexity problems - Good balance of speed and capability

docs.title: Opus (Most Capable)
docs.text:
Run with the most capable Opus model for challenging problems:

claude opus /path/to/project

Best for: - Difficult architectural decisions - Complex problem-solving - Full-project analysis - Maximum capability required

docs.title: Configuration Notes
docs.text:
• Bedrock Integration: Uses AWS Bedrock for model inference
  • Context Window: Defaults to 1M context window for Sonnet
  • No Confirmation: Configured to skip permission prompts for streamlined workflow
  • Model Selection: Easy switching between Haiku (fast), Sonnet (balanced), and Opus (capable)

docs.title: Tips and Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use Haiku for quick fixes and simple tasks
  • Use Sonnet for complex development and analysis
  • Use Opus for challenging problems requiring maximum capability
  • Ensure AWS credentials are properly configured before use
  • The wrapper script automatically handles model selection and AWS environment setup

docs.title: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
docs.text: Cloud infrastructure and services configuration guide with security-first credential management.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: AWS provides scalable cloud computing services. This section covers secure setup, CLI configuration, and best practices for managing AWS credentials with proper scope isolation.

docs.title: Installing AWS CLI v2
docs.text: AWS CLI v2 is the recommended command-line interface for AWS services.

docs.title: Linux/WSL Installation
docs.text:
# Download the installer
curl "https://awscli.amazonaws.com/awscli-exe-linux-x86_64.zip" -o "awscliv2.zip"

# Unzip
unzip awscliv2.zip

# Install
sudo ./aws/install

# Verify installation
aws --version

docs.title: macOS Installation
docs.text:
# Using Homebrew (recommended)
brew install awscli

# Or download directly
curl "https://awscli.amazonaws.com/awscli-exe-macos.zip" -o "awscliv2.zip"
unzip awscliv2.zip
sudo ./aws/install

# Verify
aws --version

docs.title: Understanding Credential Files
docs.text:
AWS uses two configuration files:

  • ~/.aws/credentials - Contains access keys (API credentials)
  • ~/.aws/config - Contains region and profile configuration

docs.title: Creating AWS Credentials via CLI
docs.text:
The easiest way to set up credentials is using the AWS CLI interactive configuration:

aws configure

This prompts for: 1. AWS Access Key ID 2. AWS Secret Access Key 3. Default region 4. Default output format

However, this creates a default profile with broad permissions. For better security, follow the profile-based approach below.

docs.title: Critical Security Principle
docs.text:
Never use static credentials with broad AWS permissions as your default profile. Instead:

  1. Use temporary credentials or IAM roles when possible
  2. Keep static credentials in separate, narrowly-scoped profiles
  3. Grant only the minimum permissions needed for each profile

docs.title: Setting Up Service-Specific Profiles
docs.text:
Create isolated credential profiles for each service. For example, to set up a Bedrock-only profile:

aws configure --profile bedrock

Enter your credentials when prompted. This creates:

In ~/.aws/credentials:

[bedrock]
aws_access_key_id = YOUR_ACCESS_KEY_ID
aws_secret_access_key = YOUR_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY

In ~/.aws/config:

[profile bedrock]
region = us-west-2
output = json

docs.title: Complete Profile Configuration Example
docs.text:
For multiple services with proper isolation:

~/.aws/credentials

# Bedrock (Claude API access only)
[bedrock]
aws_access_key_id = AKIA...
aws_secret_access_key = wJalrXUtnFEMI/K7MDENG...

# S3 (Storage only)
[s3-user]
aws_access_key_id = AKIA...
aws_secret_access_key = wJalrXUtnFEMI/K7MDENG...

~/.aws/config

# Bedrock Profile - Bedrock service only
[profile bedrock]
region = us-west-2
output = json

# S3 Profile - S3 access only
[profile s3-user]
region = us-west-2
output = json

docs.title: IAM Policy Examples
docs.text:
When creating AWS access keys for a profile, apply strict IAM policies:

Bedrock-Only Policy:

{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": [
        "bedrock:InvokeModel",
        "bedrock:InvokeModelWithResponseStream"
      ],
      "Resource": "*"
    }
  ]
}

S3-Only Policy:

{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": [
        "s3:GetObject",
        "s3:PutObject",
        "s3:ListBucket"
      ],
      "Resource": [
        "arn:aws:s3:::my-bucket",
        "arn:aws:s3:::my-bucket/*"
      ]
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Override Default Profile
docs.text:
Use any configured profile with the --profile flag:

# Use bedrock profile
aws s3 ls --profile bedrock

# Use s3-user profile
aws s3 ls --profile s3-user

docs.title: Set Default Profile for Session
docs.text:
export AWS_PROFILE=bedrock
aws s3 ls  # Uses bedrock profile

docs.title: Using Profiles with AWS SDKs
docs.text:
Most AWS SDKs (Python boto3, Node.js, etc.) respect the AWS_PROFILE environment variable:

export AWS_PROFILE=bedrock
python script.py  # Script uses bedrock credentials

docs.title: Credentials File Security
docs.text:
Ensure proper permissions on credential files:

chmod 700 ~/.aws
chmod 600 ~/.aws/credentials
chmod 600 ~/.aws/config

Never commit credential files to version control:

# In .gitignore
~/.aws/credentials
~/.aws/config

docs.title: Profile Isolation
docs.text:
• ✅ DO: Create separate profiles for each service/application
  • ❌ DON'T: Use default profile with full AWS permissions

docs.title: Credential Rotation
docs.text:
• ✅ DO: Rotate access keys regularly (quarterly minimum)
  • ❌ DON'T: Reuse the same credentials across multiple systems

docs.title: Least Privilege
docs.text:
• ✅ DO: Grant only the permissions each service needs
  • ❌ DON'T: Attach broad policies like AdministratorAccess

docs.title: Monitoring
docs.text:
• ✅ DO: Enable CloudTrail to audit credential usage
  • ✅ DO: Check CloudWatch for unusual activity
  • ❌ DON'T: Ignore access logs

docs.title: Temporary Credentials
docs.text:
• ✅ PREFER: Temporary credentials via STS AssumeRole (when possible)
  • ❌ AVOID: Long-lived static credentials for high-privilege access

docs.title: GitHub
docs.text: Essential setup and configuration for working with GitHub repositories.

docs.title: SSH Key Setup
docs.text:
SSH key generation and keychain management are covered in the Shell section. Follow that guide first to:

  1. Generate your SSH key with a passphrase
  2. Configure SSH permissions
  3. Set up SSH keychain to cache your passphrase

After completing the Shell setup, come back here to push your key to GitHub.

docs.title: Option 1: Quick Setup with GitHub CLI (Recommended)
docs.text:
The fastest way to add your SSH key to GitHub is using the GitHub CLI:

  1. Install GitHub CLI
# On Ubuntu/WSL
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install gh

# On macOS
brew install gh

# Or download from https://github.com/cli/cli/releases
  1. Authenticate with GitHub
gh auth login

Follow the prompts: - Select "GitHub.com" - Select "SSH" for git protocol - Use your existing SSH key - Authorize GitHub CLI to manage SSH keys

  1. Automatic SSH key upload

GitHub CLI will automatically detect your SSH key and upload it to your GitHub account during gh auth login.

  1. Verify setup
gh auth status

You should see confirmation of your authenticated account.

docs.title: Option 2: Manual GitHub Web Interface
docs.text:
If you prefer the web interface:

  1. Display your public key:
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

  1. Copy the entire output

  2. Go to GitHub Settings → SSH and GPG keys → New SSH key

  3. Paste your public key and give it a descriptive title (e.g., "My Laptop")

  4. Click "Add SSH key"

docs.title: Test SSH Connection
docs.text:
Verify your SSH setup works with GitHub:

ssh -T git@github.com

You should see:

Hi YOUR_USERNAME! You've successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.

docs.title: Clone a Repository
docs.text:
git clone git@github.com:USERNAME/repository.git
cd repository

docs.title: Create and Switch Branches
docs.text: git checkout -b feature/my-feature

docs.title: Make Changes and Commit

git commit -m "Describe your changes"

docs.title: Push to GitHub
docs.text: git push origin feature/my-feature

docs.title: Create a Pull Request
docs.text: After pushing, visit your repository on GitHub and create a pull request to merge your branch.

docs.title: Cloning Your First Repository
docs.text:
Your first GitHub repository can be cloned locally:

git clone git@github.com:YOUR_USERNAME/your-repo.git
cd your-repo

Then you can run Claude Code inside:

docs.title: Python
docs.text: Python development setup and package management using modern tools.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This setup uses two modern package managers: - UV: Fast, reliable Python package manager and project tool - Pixi: Cross-platform package manager compatible with conda

docs.title: Installing Indigo (Python Binary Distribution)
docs.text: For a clean, optimized Python environment, use Indigo - a standalone Python distribution.

docs.title: Download and Install
docs.text:
1. Download the latest Indigo release
curl -L https://github.com/indygreg/python-build-standalone/releases/download/20240713/cpython-3.13.0b4+20240713-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu.tar.zst -o python.tar.zst
  1. Extract to your home directory
mkdir -p ~/.python
tar -I zstd -xf python.tar.zst -C ~/.python
  1. Add to PATH

Add this to your shell configuration (.bashrc, .zshrc):

export PATH="$HOME/.python/python/install/bin:$PATH"
  1. Verify Installation
python --version

docs.text: UV is a fast, reliable package manager for Python projects.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

docs.title: Creating a New Project

cd my-project

docs.title: Adding Dependencies
docs.text:

docs.title: Running Python Scripts

docs.title: Pixi Package Manager
docs.text: Pixi is a cross-platform package manager compatible with conda environments, great for data science and scientific computing.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: curl -fsSL https://pixi.sh/install.sh | bash

docs.title: Creating a New Project
docs.text:

cd my-data-project

docs.title: Adding Dependencies
docs.text:

docs.title: Running Commands
docs.text: pixi run python script.py

docs.title: Creating Environments
docs.text:
pixi create -e analysis
pixi run -e analysis python analysis.py

docs.title: Conda Compatibility
docs.text:
Pixi automatically handles conda channels and environments:

pixi add -c conda-forge numpy

docs.title: Choosing Between UV and Pixi
docs.text: Use Case Tool Standard Python projects UV Data science / Jupyter Pixi Machine learning Pixi Web development UV CLI tools UV Scientific computing Pixi Mixed dependencies (PyPI + conda) Pixi

docs.title: With UV
docs.text:
# Create virtual environment
uv venv

# Activate
source .venv/bin/activate

# Deactivate
deactivate

docs.title: With Pixi
docs.text:
# Create environment
pixi create -e myenv

# Use environment
pixi run -e myenv python script.py

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always use virtual environments to isolate project dependencies
  • Use UV for most Python projects - it's faster and simpler
  • Use Pixi for data science - better conda ecosystem support
  • Commit lock files (uv.lock or pixi.lock) to version control
  • Document dependencies in pyproject.toml or pixi.toml

docs.title: Shell
docs.text: Unix shell configuration and environment setup for a productive development environment.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This section covers essential shell setup including SSH configuration, terminal tools, and environment variables.

docs.title: SSH Key Management
docs.text: Secure shell access is critical for development work. This section covers SSH setup with password-protected keys and keychain integration.

docs.title: Generating SSH Keys
docs.text:
SSH keys should always use a passphrase for security. When generating keys, use a strong password:

ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com" -f ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

Important: When prompted for a passphrase, enter a strong password. This protects your key if it's ever compromised.

docs.title: SSH Key Permissions
docs.text:
Ensure proper permissions on your SSH keys:

chmod 700 ~/.ssh
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
chmod 644 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

docs.title: SSH Configuration
docs.text:
Create or edit ~/.ssh/config to simplify SSH connections and optimize performance:

# SSH Connection Multiplexing and Global Defaults
Host *
    ControlPath ~/.ssh/controlmasters/%r@%h:%p
    ControlMaster auto
    ControlPersist 10m
    ServerAliveInterval 10
    ServerAliveCountMax 3
    User your-username

# GitHub
Host github.com
    HostName github.com
    User git
    IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
    AddKeysToAgent yes

# Jump Host Example
Host jumphost
    HostName jump.example.com
    ControlMaster auto
    DynamicForward 1080

# Remote Server Behind Jump Host
Host remote-server
    HostName server.example.com
    ProxyJump jumphost

Key Configuration Options:

  • ControlPath: Directory for multiplexed connections (creates .ssh/controlmasters/ dir)
  • ControlMaster auto: Automatically reuse connections
  • ControlPersist 10m: Keep connections alive for 10 minutes
  • ServerAliveInterval 10: Send keepalive every 10 seconds
  • ServerAliveCountMax 3: Disconnect after 3 missed keepalives
  • ProxyJump: Chain connections through jump host
  • DynamicForward: Enable SOCKS proxy through host

Setup multiplexing directory:

mkdir -p ~/.ssh/controlmasters
chmod 700 ~/.ssh/controlmasters

Benefits:

  • Faster connections: Reuses SSH connections, eliminates repeated authentication
  • Reliable: Keepalive prevents timeouts on idle connections
  • Secure: Jump host proxy keeps direct connections private
  • Flexible: Works with any remote host configuration

docs.title: SSH Keychain
docs.text: Use SSH keychain to securely store your SSH key passphrase in memory, eliminating the need to re-enter it for every SSH command.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
On Ubuntu/WSL:

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install ssh-askpass ssh-keychain

On macOS:

# Usually included by default
# If not: brew install ssh-askpass

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Add to your shell configuration file (.bashrc, .zshrc, or .profile):

# SSH Keychain - loads SSH key passphrase into memory
eval $(ssh-keychain -q -t 4h ~/.ssh/id_ed25519)

The -t 4h parameter sets the cache timeout to 4 hours. Adjust as needed.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. On your first SSH/Git command of the session, you'll be prompted for your SSH key passphrase
  2. Enter your password - it's stored securely in your system keychain
  3. For the next 4 hours, all SSH connections use the cached passphrase
  4. After the timeout, you'll be prompted again

This approach provides security (your key is protected with a password) and convenience (you only type it once per session).

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If prompted repeatedly for your passphrase:

# Check if ssh-agent is running
ps aux | grep ssh-agent

# Manually start ssh-agent
eval $(ssh-agent -s)

# Add key manually
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

docs.title: Bash Configuration
docs.text:
Edit ~/.bashrc:

# Add SSH Keychain
eval $(ssh-keychain -q -t 4h ~/.ssh/id_ed25519)

# Add useful aliases
alias ll='ls -lah'
alias cd..='cd ..'
alias clear-cache='rm -rf ~/.cache'

# Set default editor
export EDITOR=vim

# Add local bin to PATH
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"

docs.title: Zsh Configuration
docs.text:
Edit ~/.zshrc:

# Add SSH Keychain
eval $(ssh-keychain -q -t 4h ~/.ssh/id_ed25519)

# Add useful aliases
alias ll='ls -lah'
alias cd..='cd ..'

# Set default editor
export EDITOR=vim

# Add local bin to PATH
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"

docs.title: Essential Environment Variables
docs.text:
Set these in your shell configuration:

# Editor
export EDITOR=vim

# Language
export LANG=en_US.UTF-8
export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8

# Path additions
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"

# Git
export GIT_EDITOR=vim

docs.title: Keep SSH Keys Secure
docs.text:
• Never commit SSH keys to version control
  • Never share your private key
  • Always use strong passphrases
  • Rotate keys periodically
  • Use key files only for automated systems

docs.title: SSH Agent Security
docs.text:
• Let keychain manage your passphrase
  • Don't store unencrypted passphrases
  • Lock your computer when stepping away
  • Expire cached passphrases after reasonable time

docs.title: Command History
docs.text:
Keep your shell history clean:

# Increase history size
export HISTSIZE=10000
export HISTFILESIZE=10000

# Ignore duplicate commands
export HISTCONTROL=ignoredups

# Ignore common commands from history
export HISTIGNORE="ls:cd:pwd:history"

docs.title: Useful Shell Aliases
docs.text:
Add to your shell configuration:

# Navigation
alias ..='cd ..'
alias ...='cd ../..'
alias ll='ls -lah'
alias l='ls -la'

# Git
alias g='git'
alias gs='git status'
alias ga='git add'
alias gc='git commit'
alias gp='git push'
alias gl='git log'

# Development
alias cls='clear'
alias py='python'
alias serve='python -m http.server'

docs.title: Secure Development Environment
docs.text:
Your shell environment should be:

  • Secure: SSH keys protected with passphrases, keychain for convenience
  • Clean: Well-organized bin directories, clear PATH
  • Productive: Useful aliases, proper history management
  • Isolated: Virtual environments for projects, clear separation of concerns

docs.text: WSL enables running a Linux environment directly on Windows, providing a native Linux development experience without dual-boot or virtualization overhead.
